message: I know a few partnerships that have started from Hack Days.
It's hard to say they've proven to be optimal, but they are a decent starting point. People who go to Hack Days to build stuff for fun tend to have the "love what they do" aspect pretty well covered.
I'm sure others can agree with me... it can be really frustrating finding people who are motivated, love what they do, ambitious and dedicated :)  how have you met your co-founders and work partners?

So...it's interesting that this topic came up as I spent some time this evening writing up a proposal for a solution to this very problem.  It's an idea I've been toying with for a while but I think I might actually implement it.  I'm just not sure if the market is big enough...

Start doing something publicly. If you find a partner along the way, it may turn into something bigger / better. You're more attractive when you're implementing something. i.e. People prefer to hop on moving trains.

I prefer to work with people that I've already worked with... not necessarily in the same domain, but if I were going to start a project I'd tap people from university etc - I already know that they can deliver, what their working style is like, that they're not flakes etc
I find that hanging out behind the basketball court at the local park is a good way to meet criminals

I found meetups to be great. On one occasion you could grab the Mic and pitch to the audience. Why not pitch for a Hacker! Also these meetups are usually after work so anyone who is willing to give time after his regular work is Level1 motivated. I keep going on about letslunch.com but I really think it is an easy way of getting in touch with interesting people. And the /dev/random aspect of it makes it more probable that you actually meet someone interesting. And you know that after 1h it is over if you get annoyed...

Hackerspaces. I help started one and am actively involved -as a result I know people all around the country - and REALLY know people all around the state and surrounding state - with an amazing spread of technical backgrounds. My own hackerspace, for reference: FUBARLabs.com

@micrypt I love barcamp/hackdays to find partners as you get to see what people are like. We're looking for some html/css/front end people to come join http://www.LiveFanChat.com in case you know of anyone interested in sports and not afraid of equity roles.
is there a local twitter-ish app to talk to hackers in my area?

@3DRealtime - I suggest checking out hackerspaces.org - theres spaces all over the country (and if youre not in the US, theres a ton in europe too) that you can meet a lot of like minded tech people. What area you in?
Stop trying to meet a partner in crime. If you can't do it yourself, you're not entrepreneurial enough. Find a desk job.
